['Assertion - The act of stating something confidently and forcefully as if it were true.', 'Affirmation - A positive statement or confirmation, expressing approval or belief in something.', 'Adherence - The action of following a rule, standard, or plan closely.', 'Assumption - An idea or theory that is taken for granted without proof.', 'Belief - Acceptance that something exists or is true, especially based on faith or trust.', 'Conviction - A firmly held opinion or belief; strong personal principle.', 'Hypothesis - A proposed explanation made on the basis of limited evidence as a starting point for further investigation.', 'Premise - An assumption or statement from which something is inferred or an argument is concluded.', 'Postulation - The act of suggesting a theory or idea, often without proof or strong evidence.', 'Proposition - A statement that expresses a judgment or opinion; an assertion.', 'Proposition - A formal suggestion or plan put forward for consideration or discussion by others.', 'Presumption - An assumption made based on little or no evidence.', 'Premise - The fundamental basis or underlying principle of something, often taken as the case.', 'Assumption - The act of taking an idea to be true without proof; accepting it as a given fact.', 'Hypothesis - A tentative assumption made in order to test its validity or to illustrate a general point.', 'Postulate - To assume something is true, often used when no evidence exists.', 'Conjecture - An inference based on scanty evidence; an unproven conclusion drawn from incomplete information.', 'Assertion - The act of stating something confidently and forcefully as if it were known to be true.', 'Hypothesis - A supposition or proposed explanation made on the basis of limited evidence before any proof is obtained.', 'Premise - An accepted proposition from which a conclusion can be drawn; taken for granted in an argument.']
